Coconut Flour Sponge Cake

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to a delightful and healthy baking adventure where we explore the magic of coconut flour! If you’re looking for a light, airy cake that caters to gluten-free diets without sacrificing flavor, our Coconut Flour Sponge Cake is the perfect recipe for you. Made with simple ingredients like eggs, honey or maple syrup, and creamy coconut oil, this sponge cake is not only delicious but also incredibly easy to whip up. In just under 30 minutes of baking time, you can enjoy a fluffy, moist cake that’s ideal for any occasion, from birthday celebrations to afternoon tea. With its subtle coconut flavor and versatile nature, this sponge cake can be paired with fresh fruits, whipped cream, or a drizzle of chocolate for an elegant dessert. Let’s dive into this easy, wholesome recipe that will surely impress your friends and family!

Ingredients

coconut flour

Coconut flour is highly absorbent, so it’s important not to substitute it cup-for-cup for regular flour. If you don't have coconut flour, you can substitute it with almond flour but will need to adjust the quantity and add extra eggs for moisture. When measuring coconut flour, spoon it into the measuring cup and level it off to avoid packing it down.

eggs

Eggs provide structure and moisture to the cake. If you're looking for an egg substitute, you can use flaxseed meal (1 tablespoon flaxseed meal + 2.5 tablespoons water = 1 egg) or applesauce (1/4 cup applesauce = 1 egg). Be mindful that substitutes may alter the texture slightly.

honey or maple syrup

Both honey and maple syrup add sweetness and moisture to the cake. If you're looking for a lower glycemic index option, consider using agave nectar or stevia (adjust according to taste). For a more intense flavor, try using brown sugar or coconut sugar.

baking powder

Baking powder is crucial for leavening. If you’re out of baking powder, you can make your own by combining 1 tsp of baking soda and 1 tsp of cream of tartar. Ensure your baking powder is fresh for optimal rise.

vanilla extract

Vanilla extract enhances the flavor profile of the cake. You can substitute it with almond extract for a different flavor, but use it sparingly (1/2 tsp) as it is more potent. For a natural option, scrape the seeds from a vanilla bean pod.

salt

Salt balances the sweetness and enhances the overall flavor. If you need a salt substitute, opt for sea salt or Himalayan pink salt. If you’re watching sodium intake, you can reduce the amount or omit it, but this may affect flavor.

coconut oil (melted)

Coconut oil adds moisture and a subtle coconut flavor. If you don't have coconut oil, you can substitute with unsalted butter or another neutral oil like grapeseed or canola oil. Make sure to melt it before using for better incorporation.

milk (dairy or non-dairy)

Milk adds moisture. You can substitute dairy milk with almond milk, coconut milk, or oat milk for a dairy-free version. If using non-dairy milk, opt for unsweetened varieties to avoid altering the sweetness of the cake.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the oven

    Begin by preheating your oven to 350°F (175°C). This step is crucial for ensuring your cake bakes evenly. If you skip this, the cake might not rise properly.

  • Step 2: Prepare the cake pan

    Grease an 8-inch round cake pan with coconut oil or line it with parchment paper. This will prevent the cake from sticking and make it easier to remove after baking.

  • Step 3: Mix dry ingredients

    In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of coconut flour, 1 teaspoon of baking powder, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Stir the dry ingredients together to ensure they are evenly distributed. Coconut flour absorbs a lot of moisture, so make sure to mix well.

  • Step 4: Whisk wet ingredients

    In another bowl, whisk together 4 eggs, 1/3 cup of honey (or maple syrup), 1/4 cup of melted coconut oil, 1/2 cup of milk (dairy or non-dairy), and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Whisk until the mixture is smooth and well combined. This step is important to incorporate air into the mixture, which helps the cake rise.

  • Step 5: Combine wet and dry ingredients

    Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients. Mix until well combined. The batter will be thick due to the coconut flour, so use a spatula to scrape down the sides and ensure everything is fully mixed.

  • Step 6: Transfer to cake pan

    Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan and use a spatula to smooth the top. This helps create an even surface that will bake uniformly.

  • Step 7: Bake the cake

    Place the cake in the preheated oven and bake for 20-25 minutes. Check for doneness by inserting a toothpick into the center; if it comes out clean, the cake is ready. If not, give it a few more minutes.

  • Step 8: Cool the cake

    Once baked, allow the cake to cool in the pan for about 5-10 minutes. Then, transfer it to a wire rack to cool completely. Cooling completely is important to ensure the cake holds its shape when sliced.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is coconut flour and how is it different from regular flour?

Coconut flour is a gluten-free flour made from dried coconut meat. It is much more absorbent than regular flour, so recipe adjustments may be necessary when substituting it.

How do I properly measure coconut flour?

Scoop the flour into your measuring cup and level it off with a straight edge. Avoid packing it down, as this can result in using too much flour.

Can I substitute the eggs in this recipe?

Yes, you can use flax eggs or chia eggs as a substitute. To make one flax egg, mix 1 tablespoon of ground flaxseed with 2.5 tablespoons of water and let it sit for 5 minutes.

What can I use instead of honey or maple syrup?

You can use agave nectar or another liquid sweetener. Just remember that different sweeteners may change the flavor and consistency slightly.

How do I know when the cake is done baking?

Insert a toothpick into the center of the cake; if it comes out clean or with a few crumbs, the cake is done. If there’s wet batter on the toothpick, it needs more time.

What’s the best way to grease the cake pan?

You can use coconut oil or butter to grease the pan. Use a paper towel to spread a thin layer over the bottom and sides of the pan.

How can I prevent the cake from sticking to the pan?

In addition to greasing the pan, you can also dust it lightly with a bit of coconut flour after greasing, which helps create a non-stick surface.

What should I do if my batter is too thick?

If your batter seems too thick, you can add a little extra milk (dairy or non-dairy) a tablespoon at a time until it reaches a pourable consistency.

How can I store leftover cake?

Store the cake in an airtight container at room temperature for 2-3 days, or refrigerate it for up to a week. You can also freeze it for longer storage.

What are some common mistakes to avoid when baking?

Avoid opening the oven door too often, as this can cause the cake to sink. Also, make sure to measure your ingredients accurately for the best results.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This cake is naturally gluten-free due to the use of coconut flour. For dairy-free options, use almond milk or coconut milk. To make it vegan, substitute eggs with flax eggs (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 3 tablespoons water per egg) and use maple syrup as the sweetener. Ensure that the baking powder is gluten-free if necessary.

Pairings

Pair the Coconut Flour Sponge Cake with fresh berries such as strawberries, blueberries, or raspberries for a burst of flavor and color. A dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of coconut whipped cream enhances the tropical feel. For beverages, consider pairing with a light herbal tea, a glass of coconut water, or a sparkling lemonade to balance the sweetness of the cake.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Coconut Flour Sponge Cake at room temperature, dusted with powdered sugar or drizzled with a light honey glaze for added sweetness. Garnish with mint leaves for a fresh touch. For special occasions, layer the cake with coconut cream and fresh fruit for a more decadent dessert or serve it as a base for a trifle with layers of yogurt and fruit.

#

Coconut Flour Sponge Cake

40 min
$5
150 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 8

Allergens:

Eggs

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreePaleoLow-Carb

Cuisine:

AmericanTropical

Course:

DessertSnack

Tags:

DessertCakeCoconut

Description

A light and fluffy sponge cake made with coconut flour, perfect for any occasion!

Ingredients

  • coconut flour: 1 cup
  • eggs: 4
  • honey or maple syrup: 1/3 cup
  • baking powder: 1 tsp
  • vanilla extract: 1 tsp
  • salt: 1/4 tsp
  • coconut oil (melted): 1/4 cup
  • milk (dairy or non-dairy): 1/2 cup

Date Created:

11/16/2024
